headline: Birth of the Academy
text: The Academy was first founded in 1927, but it didn't create the categories for the awards and, therefore, the ceremony we know today, until the year after

headline: The first Oscars in history
mediaCaption: First attendants of the Academy Awards

headline: Oscars locations throughout the years
text: This is the location in which the Oscars have been celebrated in the past years: the Dolby Theatre. Some other venues that have held the Academy Awards ceremony since it begun are very close to each other. Maybe Hollywood stars don't like to move around a lot!
mediaCaption: Oscars ceremony venues throughout the years

headline: Leak prevention
text: Up until this year, the press knew about the winners before they were announced in the ceremony. However, Los Angeles Times slipped up and printed the winners in an early evening edition; before the ceremony. From then onwards, the press wouldn't be given the names of the winners beforehand.
mediaCaption: A copy of an old Los Angeles Times

headline: Hattie McDaniel becomes the first African American to win an Oscar
text: Hattie McDaniel was the first African American to be nominated and win an Oscar. She won best supporting actress for her role in Gone With the Wind.
mediaCaption: Hattie McDaniel (1940) with Oscar plaque for best supprting actress

headline: Mom, I'm on TV!
text: This is the year in which the Academy Award were first televised on the US

headline: The Oscars go international
text: Since 1969, the Academy Awards ceremony has been broadcasted internationally. Only 16 years after its first televisation in the US!
mediaCaption: Barbra Streisand on the first ever internationally broadcasted Oscars

headline: Titanic makes the history
text: Titanic won a total of 11 awards. This was also the most-watched ceremony in history, with 87 million estimated viewers in the United States.
mediaCaption: In 1998, Titanic not only won the best picture, but other 10 awards, breaking the records for most nominations earned by a single movie ("All About Eve")

headline: [Black] Girls to the front!
text: Halle Berry became the first black woman to win an Academy Award for Best Actress. She dedicated the honor to "every nameless, faceless woman of color that now has a chance because this door tonight has been opened."
mediaCaption: Halle Berry holding victoriously her statuette

headline: Heath Ledger wins posthumous Oscar (2009)
text: After his sudden death at 28 from an accidental overdose of prescription medications , his family accepted his best supporting actor award, for his towering performance as the Joker in Batman movie The Dark Knight.

headline: Directors at the top
text: Steve Mcqueen is the first African-American director to have a film win in the Best Picture category: "12 Years a Slave". Alfonso Cuarón became the first Latinx to win Best Directing, with his movie "Gravity".
mediaCaption: McQueen (second from the left) and Cuarón (on the far right) alongside Scorsese, Payne, and O.Russell,

headline: A year to remember
text: Parasite became the first film in a language other than English to win Best Picture. Joaquin Phoenix was the second actor to win an Oscar for playing the Joker.
mediaCaption: Bong Joon-Ho having fun with his statuettes. They're kissing. Muac!

headline: Chloé Zhao wins Oscar for Best Director
text: Chloé Zhao won Best Director with Nomadland making her the first Asian woman (and only the second woman, after Kathryn Bigelow, ever) to win the category.
mediaCaption: Chloé Zhao backstage with her Oscars

headline: Firsts in history from the latest Oscars
text: In 2022 Ariana DeBose has been the first openly queer woman of color to win an Oscar for acting. Troy Kotsur is the first deaf man to win a statuette for his acting. Also, CODA  is the first movie from a streaming service and the first movie to debut at Sundance to win Best Picture.
mediaCaption: Ariana DeBose posing with her statuette
